reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s illustrative “value as product of factors” toy model (which explicitly assumes independent uniform factors) and argues that correlations could make ‘multiplicative failure’ less likely, weakening the ‘eutopia is fragile’ intuition. This is somewhat central because that section supports the broader ‘no easy eutopia’ framing, but it is not foundational: much of the essay’s case (e.g., the later bounded/unbounded-value-function analysis) does not rely on independence or even the multiplicative toy model. Strength is low because (i) the essay presents the independence/product model as a heuristic/illustration rather than a defended empirical claim, and (ii) the critique doesn’t show that realistic correlations would in fact substantially increase the mass of mostly-great futures; correlations could also increase fragility depending on structure. The point is mostly correct and clearly stated, with no dead weight and a single focused issue.
title: Correlated failure factors may overstate multiplicative fragility estimates
